thread.title_full: NASA launches asteroid mission to protect humanity from apocalyptic 'threat' of doomsday space rock - Mirror Online

author: Jasper Hamill
title: NASA launches asteroid mission to protect humanity from apocalyptic 'threat' of doomsday space rock
text:
One plucky little robot is set to play a vital role in saving humanity from being wiped out in an asteroid apocalypse.
NASA has launched the first stage in a long mission to build a spaceship capable of steering space rocks away from our planet.
The space agency has vowed to design a robotic craft capable of demonstrating " planetary defence asteroid deflection " technology which can redirect dangerous asteroids on a collision course with Earth.
Its " Asteroid Redirect Mission " will then be sent on a mission to alter the course of a chunk of space rock and then steer it into orbit around the moon.
If NASA's redirection technique is shown to be effective, it is likely to inspire the design of a much larger craft capable of preventing doomsday asteroids from smashing into our planet.
Lifesaver: An artist's impression of a NASA robot picking up a boulder from the face of an asteroid
"The mission both uses and expands NASA’s ability to detect, characterize and mitigate the threat these space rocks pose to our home plane," the space agency wrote.
NASA wants to demonstrate the Earth-saving potential of a technique which involves pushing and pulling at a space rock in a bid to change the direction it's travelling in.
"While at a large asteroid, the spacecraft will demonstrate a 'slow-push' planetary defense asteroid deflection technique during the mission," NASA added.
"This uses the spacecraft and boulder's combined gravitational pull to attempt to change the course of an asteroid."
Getty Too close for comfort: NASA wants to bat asteroids away from Earth
To demonstrate this experimental - but potentially planet-saving - technology - NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory has asked private companies to submit their own designs for a robot capable of grabbing a 20 tonne, six metre wide boulder from an asteroid and then placing it in orbit around the moon.
Although this sounds like a relatively simple task, it requires a "20-fold improvement" in the propulsion technology which is used to power crafts through the freezing vacuum of space.
The mission also has several other key objectives, including one scheme which could help make the United States even richer than it already is.
NBC Space for expansion: American business moguls could one day build mine valuable substances from asteroids
"Redirecting and 'parking' a large asteroid boulder within reach of human and robotic explorers also will provide American commercial enterprises their first opportunities to investigate the viability of mining asteroids for precious metals and other resources," NASA added.
The mission will also play a role in helping humans get to Mars and "set the stage for future integrated crewed and robotic vehicle operations in deep space".
"The Asteroid Redirect Mission brings together the best of NASA's science, technology and human exploration efforts to accomplish several important objectives that are critical elements during our journey to Mars," NASA said.
The world has been gripped by doomsday fever in recent months, with a variety of apocalyptic predictions failing to come true.
Getty Images Extinction: Meteor strike is thought to have blasted dinosaurs into oblivion
But it is inevitable that Planet Earth will one day be in the crosshairs of a comet which could be as big as the one which wiped out the dinosaurs, or even one small enough to simply annihilate a small town.
